title: Chat shouldn't go away when someone mutes you
body: Recently had a toxic player send me a friend request post-game. They proceeded to type some more toxic things and then mute me. Whatever. My issue here is that, when they muted me, their chat log disappeared from my side of the server, so not only could I not screenshot it for my formal report, but that there is no easy way to send a report to Riot. This is a feature that could very easily be fixed, and should be.

This is so horrendously incorrect. But, let's assume your logic is sound throughout all of Riot. That means that the entirety of League would also not be anything Riot could act on, since the whole game is "opt in" and no one forces you to play.

You opt in to League - you do not opt in to communication with toxic players.

Unless, though, you actually, you know, **opt in (add)** a toxic player as a **friend**. If someone isn't your friend, don't add them as a friend. Riot respects players' privacy and allows friends to merely use League DMs to communicate - not to have a moderated chatting experience.

So, if you've been friends with someone for a long time, then they drop a bunch of slurs on you and mute you, you're telling me that should be allowed? 

System is still broken.

No... but it's like how you can't go crying to your phone company "omg this person who i willingly gave my phone number to and represented that we were communicating as friends is now spamming me" and expect them to do anything more than tell you to block them.

OTOH, if some random number starts spamming you, you never opted into it, **then** you have a reasonable expectation your phone company will do something.

Apples to oranges.

Also, I'd like to think Riot has more integrity than a phone company.

Okay... let's use another example:

You agree to go to coffee with a friend. You're drinking your coffee when the friend starts hurling insults at you. You call the police and say "waah waah he was being a jerk". The police are going to say "well, you went willingly and could've walked away anytime".

On the contrary, if someone you don't know, and you didn't try to talk to starts harassing you, the police will take action.

One is opt in. One is not.

This is partially true, but partially not, as speaking with the Riot Supporter who unbanned me they took into account the person's, who sent a ticket in to get me banned, conversation they had with me after the game was over through direct message how they were going to make sure I got banned so I didn't do "stupid st" ever again and how I was an awful person for playing differently than them and even though our scores were virtually identical and all lanes but me made the kha'zix 9 and 0 the loss was my fault, etc etc and on and on. 

Everything you say is passively monitored in that it is recorded in some form. 

Beware.

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

You opt into direct message chat that is unrelated to what happens in the game. 

While in the game, the purpose of chat is to communicate towards objectives in the game. You don’t have much control over whether someone’s going to be a jerk to you in game: you’ll still be stuck with them regardless of whether or not you mute the other player. That’s not the case with the messages sent through the client.

This is still irrelevant. What if you've been friends with someone for quite some time, and they decide through the in-game messaging to one day drop a bunch of garbage at you in the direct message? There still, regardless of anyone's opinion on my specific scenario earlier, is no way to report them if they choose to then mute you.

Which is something that should be fixed.

Someone on your friend's list calling you a garbage player? They're unlikely to punish for that, again, because you've got two steps to eradicating their communication with you. 

It doesn't matter if you don't have access to their chat. If you have their name, and general gist of what they did that was inappropriate, then you can send in a ticket and have them look into that player's interactions.
